description: From Middle English spayen, spaien, from the Anglo-Norman espeier, equivalent to the Old French espeer (“to cut with a sword”), from espee (“sword”), whence the Modern French épée.

entries.meaning: The act of spaying an animal.

verbs.description: spay (third-person singular simple present spays, present participle spaying, simple past spayed, past participle spayed or (obsolete) spade)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To remove or destroy the ovaries and/or uterus (of a female animal) so that she cannot become pregnant.
examples: We're having our cat spayed as we don't want her having kittens.

verbs.description: spay (third-person singular simple present spays, present participle spaying, simple past and past participle spayed)

entries.meaning: Alternative form of spae (to foretell or divine)
